Penobscot McCrum recognizes that even good PSM/RMP Programs require constant attention and
improvement. The PSM/RMP program is considered to be a set of living documents and
procedures that will require constant attention, development, and revision before safety truly
becomes second nature.

Penobscot McCrum will continue to improve PSM/RMP and safety performance by emphasizing the
following elements of their PSM/RMP Program:

(1) EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION: Employee Participation is the key to a successful program.
Ammonia Process Managers and Operators have been deeply involved in verifying P&ID's,
Developing and updating the Standard Operating Procedures, and performing the documented
Preventive Maintenance Inspections and they will continue to monitor progress.

(2) SITE SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS: Penobscot McCrum has implemented additional ammonia
detection equipment and an emergency alarm system that will notify the community, up to two miles
at 65 Db, in the event of an unintentional release. This system is tested monthly to ensure
operational status.

(3) PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS: All recommendations developed during the Process Hazards
Analysis (PHA) Revalidation were designed to improve the safety performance of the Ammonia
Refrigeration System. Penobscot McCrum will evaluate each PHA recommendation and document
the action taken.

(4) AUDITS: Programs are audited every 3 years as required by the OSHA PSM to improve Safety
Performance as well as to verify compliance with the PSM/RMP Regulations.

(5) STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES: SOP's are certified annually to be current and
correct. They are revised as often as necessary to keep them current and correct.

(6) TRAINING: Documented Orientation Training (both classroom and On-the-Job) is provided
employees before ammonia related work assignments are given. Renewal training, including
documented training tests, are provided annually.

IV. DESCRIPTION OF THE Penobscot McCrum ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION
PROGRAM

Penobscot McCrum annually conducts in house emergency action training and has developed a
strong relationship with the local public emergency response agencies. Penobscot McCrum has
participated in a field training exercise with focused on an unified response to an unintentional
ammonia release situation.

Penobscot McCrum conducts triennial PSM/RMP compliance audits of their PSM/RMP program to
identify strengths and weaknesses and make improvements. Penobscot McCrum considers the
PSM/RMP manuals to be a living documents that must be updated and revised regularly to maintain
their viability and usefulness.

Penobscot McCrum has and insists on employee participation from their ammonia process
operators in all aspects of the development, implementation, and integration of their PSM/RMP
program.

Penobscot McCrum provides a comprehensive, computer based, user friendly training program and
management system with specific training modules available for each ammonia process employee.
Penobscot McCrum maintains a pro-active open-door policy toward neighbors and concerned
community citizens. Facility tours and risk management discussions are scheduled and conducted
upon written request.

V. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENTAL RELEASE HISTORY

There have been no releases of ammonia during the past five years that resulted in an injury, or that
had an off-site impact, or that resulted in significant property damage either on-site or off-site.

VI. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Facility employees have been trained to respond to accidental ammonia releases with defensive
measures; shelter in place, evacuate if necessary, give notice, and move to daily set assembly
areas. The site emergency plan is coordinated with local Public Emergency Responders.

VII. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

I. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES

Penobscot McCrum recognizes management's responsibility to protecting it's employees,
equipment, property, and the environment. The safety and health of all personnel are very important.
The control of ammonia release incidents has been and will continue to be the basic responsibility of
all Penobscot McCrum personnel who operate their ammonia refrigeration process.

The Penobscot McCrum PSM/RMP program assigns and documents the specific responsibilities for
developing, implementing and integrating the OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP standards into its
ammonia operating and management systems. The Penobscot McCrum PSM/RMP program
focuses attention on making PSM/RMP an important part of its operation.

Penobscot/McCrum believes that employee participation is the key to a successful PSM/RMP
program. Operating level employees, particularly the refrigeration manager has been deeply
involved and he (along with the refrigeration system operators) assumes the major responsibility for
operating the hazardous material process safely.

The Penobscot McCrum emergency action plan has been developed in house and has been
coordinated with the local public emergency response agencies. All Penobscot McCrum employees
have received documented emergency action training.

II. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Penobscot McCrum operates an ammonia refrigeration system. Ammonia is a common industrial
chemical with applications in a large number of industries such as agriculture, water treatment, food
storage warehouses, pharmaceuticals, heat treating and many, many more. Ammonia has been
listed by both EPA and OSHA as a hazardous substance.
